raw_text:
Pavey focuses on indoor success
 
 Jo Pavey will miss January's View From Great Edinburgh International Cross Country to focus on preparing for the European Indoor Championships in March.
 
 The 31-year-old was third behind Hayley Yelling and Justyna Bak in last week's European Cross Country Championships but she prefers to race on the track. "It was great winning bronze but I'm wary of injuries and must concentrate on the indoor season," she said. "Because of previous injuries I don't even run up hills in training." Pavey, who came fifth in the 5,000m at the Athens Olympics, helped the British cross country team win the team silver medal in Heringsdorf last week. She is likely to start her 3,000m season with a race in either Boston or Stuttgart at the end of January.

tinyllama:1.1b:
Pavy focuses on indoor success
Jo Pavey will miss January's View From Great Edinburgh International Cross Country to prepare for the European Indoor Championships in March. The 31-year-old athlete is more comfortable running on a track, as she has previously injured herself while competing on hills. As the year draws to a close, Pavey will instead focus on indoor events and aim to improve her indoor times. She is likely to start her season with either a Boston or Stuttgart race towards the end of January.

The 31-year-old athlete has been consistently competitive in cross country, but opted to prioritize indoor track events over the hills of a traditional outdoor season. Pavey, who came fifth at the 2016 Athens Olympics and is a 3,000m world champion, intends to run up hills in training before embarking on her indoor campaign.

Summary:

Jo Pavey will miss the View From Great Edinburgh International Cross Country in January to focus on preparing for the European Indoor Championships in March. Despite winning bronze at the recent European Cross Country Championships, Pavey prefers racing on the track and is cautious about injuries. She does not even run up hills during training due to past injuries. Pavey, who competed in the 5,000m race at the Athens Olympics and helped the British cross country team win a silver medal in Heringsdorf, is expected to begin her 3,000m season in either Boston or Stuttgart at the end of January.

She plans to kick off her 3,000m season with races in either Boston or Stuttgart towards the end of January.
